entry.title: Does Call of Duty Black Ops 6 support splitscreen co-op?
entry.summary:
Call of Duty Black Ops 6 splitscreen co-op would be a blast from the past for many, but it's still a feature that's highly requested by players. Being able to team up for multiplayer matches or zombies sounds like a fantastic idea for a Friday night.
Will there be Call of Duty Black Ops 6 splitscreen co-op?
Activision has provided a few details about Black Ops 6 through a short Q&A section on its support website. ‚ÄúSplit-screen gameplay (two players sharing a screen) for Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 will be available on Xbox Series X|S and PlayStation 5," said Activision. "To ensure performance integrity, split-screen gameplay will not be supported on Xbox One or PlayStation 4.‚Äù
Black Ops 6 will have splitscreen co-op but there's a catch.
Unfortunately, the PS4 and Xbox One versions won't support Black Ops 6 splitscreen co-op, at least from day one of its launch.
It's great to see splitscreen co-op still being supported in 2024, and the Call of Duty series has a history of implementing the feature into its games. Last year's Modern Warfare 3 has it, for example.
Splitscreen shooters on PS4 and Xbox One
Now that Activision has sunset splitscreen functionality within its PS4 and Xbox One ports of Call of Duty games, you don't want that seat next to you completely empty. Thankfully, there are still some shooters you can play with a pal with split-screen on the older consoles. One example is the Borderlands series, including the most recent Tiny Tina's Wonderlands. You can hook up two controllers and get as much loot as you can gather together.
Tiny Tina's Wonderlands has splitscreen co-op
If you're on the Xbox One, the Halo Master Chief Collection is a good way to go. You can play through the campaigns with a buddy, and you can wreck fools online as well with some split-screen action just like the old days.

entry.title: Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Zombies mode, explained
entry.summary:
Black Ops has been known to have some of the best Zombies modes, thanks to its highly entertaining maps. The sixth iteration will continue this tradition with an all-new undead challenge. Here's what you can expect in Call of Duty: Black Ops 6's Zombies mode.
What to expect in Black Ops 6 Zombies
Get ready to relive the nostalgia as Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 brings back the classic round-based Zombies mode, a feature that was dearly missed in the latest MW3 Zombies. Prepare to face endless hordes of zombies, with each round escalating the challenge with more formidable foes.
Terminus and Liberty Falls are the two new round-based Zombies maps. We've seen a glimpse of some locations featuring a tropical-esque map in the trailer.
As for the timeline, Black Ops 6 Zombies takes place sometime after Black Ops Cold War, continuing the Dark Aether narrative that has been a central theme in the previous games. It isn't clear if this will also involve Modern Warfare 3's Dark Aether Rifts, but this entry may not be a part of the BO universe.
Pack-a-Punch and power-ups will likely be available throughout the map. Specifically, the GobbleGums will make their epic return, currently available for purchase in the Vault Edition. These unique abilities, such as the Burned Out GobbleGum that makes zombies burst into fire, were a hit in Black Ops 3 and are sure to add a new dimension to your gameplay in Black Ops 6's Zombies mode.
Image via Activision
Operator skins are also available to go along with the Zombies mode. This includes the Warden of Alcatraz skin, Brutus, and the Reborn skin, Klaus. These Operators can be equipped during the Black Ops 6 Open Beta, and you can check out our guide on this to see when it starts.
Like many Zombies entries, Easter Eggs can be found throughout the Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Zombies map. These hidden gems typically provide challenges to embark on as a solo player or with a team.

entry.title: How to get the Dreamer‚Äôs Wrath mod in Warframe
entry.summary:
Mods are an integral part of unlocking the deeper aspects of Warframe's sandbox. While a lot of mods are stat boosts that heavily improve a particular aspect of your gear, others can completely change the way that gear functions or even improve the experience a ton. One such mod not only adds a new system for your melee weapon but also improves that system considerably. Here's how to get the Dreamer's Wrath mod in Warframe.
Where to get the Dreamer's Wrath mod in Warframe
Image via Digital Extremes.
The Dreamer's Wrath mod is acquired through the Alchemy mission type, found on the node Cambire on Deimos. If you don't have access to this mission yet, you'll need to progress the Warframe story until you've completed the Whispers in the Walls main quest. The quest unlocks the Alchemy mission type, along with several other Entrati Labs levels.
Once you get into it, progress through the mission until you've completed four rotations (bringing the Conversion Process to 100% four times). This gives you a Rotation C reward, which offers a 6% chance to drop Dreamer's Wrath.
Alongside Dreamer's Wrath, Rotation C of this Alchemy mission provides the following rewards at the following chances:
1,200x Endo - 20%
Mandonel Receiver - 16%
Mandonel Stock - 16%
Condition's Perfect - 12%
Master's Edge - 12%
Opportunity's Reach - 12%
Discipline's Merit - 6%
Is the Dreamer's Wrath mod worth using?
Dreamer's Wrath is a melee mod that enables Tennokai, a system that improves Heavy Attacks when timed correctly. Compared to other Tennokai mods, this mod increases the chance to trigger a Tennokai attack by 50% and critical damage of these attacks by 32%. If you want to have Tennokai on your weapon, there aren't many mods better than Dreamer's Wrath. The immense improvements to the system make it a beast in your arsenal.

entry.title: System Shock remakers Nightdive Studios are remastering The Thing
entry.summary: Computer Artworks' 2002 videogame adaptation of 1982 movie The Thing was a ghoulish and gripping third-person shooter with some terrific mechanics that weren't quite fleshed out, flesh being the operative word. For instance: you can enlist surviving soldiers as squadmates, but are they really surviving soldiers, or are they human-shaped warrens of teeth and mandibles poised to split open and shower you in digestive juices? You have a limited supply of blood tests with which to determine whether any people you rescue are Things in waiting - and even as you're worrying about them, they're casting suspicious eyes at you, care of some embryonic "trust" and "fear" systems. Sadly, much of this acute paranoia could be easily gamed out in practice - back in 2002, I deduced that contact with enemies increased the odds of infection, and adopted a policy of shooting anyone who'd been in my squad for too long. But it's the kind of system an intelligent remake could pounce upon and have fun with. Sadly, Nightdive are not working on a remake, like their previous System Shock remakes. They've just announced that they're making a remaster, due later this year. Still, I will take a Thing remaster and thus, the opportunity to write more about The Thing, over no remaster at all. entry.title: Half Sword's demo is a chivalric edition of Gang Beasts in which people are disemboweled for hats
entry.summary:
Stare into an abyss for long enough and, as Nietzsche wrote, a mostly naked man will wobble out of the abyss and try to murder you with a mattock. Inasmuch as can be told in the absence of dialogue or a text preamble, the naked man wants to murder you because you, and not he, are in possession of a hat. The hat makes you look like an eraser pencil from Forbidden Planet. It's the kind of headgear worn by the kind of criminal Batman's too grown-up to fight anymore. But it has, nonetheless, roused in this under-dressed stranger a sense of Dionysian frenzy. He will do anything for that hat - hewing your arms off, ripping your intestines out, tearing the skin from your ribcage. And you, in turn, will do anything to rob him of that mattock, because by the gods, it looks a lot more dangerous than the candlestick you're trying to fend him off with.
There are many such lost souls in the bleak, midnight world of the Half Sword demo - all lurking near candle-lit piles of randomly spawned hammers, stools, barrels, axes and lengths of wood, all subject to unforgivably authentic physics and cursor-based attacks that conspire to transform every scuffle into a Monty Python blooper reel.
